results.title: Some like it hot [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Billy Wilder and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: Two jazz musicians (played brilliantly by Jack Lemmon and Tony Curtis) witness the St. Valentine’s Day Massacre and elude their gangster pursuers by disguising themselves as women and joining an all-girl band headed for Miami. Billy Wilder and I.A.L. Diamond had no doubts that they were making the funniest film of their careers when they created this superb comedy. Marilyn Monroe plays a singer in one of her best performances ever.

results.title: Snow White and the seven dwarfs [DVD]
results.creator_credit: David D. Hand, Walt Disney and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: This film is regarded as a milestone in filmmaking as Walt Disney’s first full-length animated feature. Adapted from Grimm’s Fairy Tales, the film is the fairytale of Snow White, the beautiful princess whose life is threatened by the jealous Queen. Snow White finds safe haven with the seven dwarfs: Doc, Happy, Grumpy, Sleepy, Sneezy, Bashful and Dopey until a mysterious old woman arrives with a poison apple. Three years in the making, this feature propagated new developments in animation, using an unprecedented amount of man-hours in the creation of realistic movement on screen. This film is imbued in bountiful humour and music and of course striking animation. Originally billed as a children’s film, “Snow White and the seven dwarfs” is a film that from the outset had the ability to appeal across age brackets.

results.title: Akira [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Katsuhiro Otomo, Shunzo Kato, Ryohei Suzuki and Akira Committee
results.brief_description: Akira is set in Neo-Tokyo, 2019. The city is rebuilding after World War III. Kaneda and Tetsuo, two high-school dropouts, are members of a joy-riding motorcycle gang. They stumble upon a secret government project to develop telekinetic humans, apparently for use as weapons. The most powerful of these subjects is Akira, a being shrouded in mystery. The film is based on the popular graphic novel of the same name, which has achieved cult status in Japan. Animation and visual effects are outstanding in this spectacular and often disturbing vision of urban apocalypse. NB: THIS IS NOT A CHILDRENS’ FEATURE AND IS RECOMMENDED FOR MATURE AUDIENCES.

constellations_other.name: Future forward; cyberpunk manifestations, fantasy and world building
constellations_other.description: Science fiction and cyberpunk are often powerful projections of the future, which may act as dystopic warnings or strive for an optimistic outcome where societies rise above adversity.

results.title: The Howling
results.creator_credit: Joe Dante, Jack Conrad, Michael Finnell and AVCO Embassy Pictures
results.brief_description: Joe Dante’s ‘The Howling’ is a witty and frightening update of the classic Universal Studio werewolf movies. Aided by a heavily referential screenplay by John Sayle’s and Terrence Winkless, (adapted from the Gary Brandner novel) it pays equal amount homage as well as being a fresh reinvention of the genre. Dee Wallace plays Karen White, a feisty reporter on the trail of a serial killer (Robert Picardo). After a frightening confrontation with the killer which leaves him dead and her traumatized, Karen’s doctor (Patrick Macnee) recommends her to take some time off. Under his advice Karen heads off to the ‘The Colony’, a secluded hideaway full of very strange residents harboring a terrifying secret. Joe Dante peppers the film with plenty of horror film references (many of the characters are named after Werewolf movie directors) and includes a slew of sly cameos like John Sayles and B-movie mogul Roger Corman. Cast includes John Carradine, Dennis Dugan, Christopher Stone, Belinda Balaski, Kevin, McCarthy, Slim Pickins and Elizabeth Brooks.

results.title: The Body snatcher
results.creator_credit: Robert Wise, Val Lewton and RKO Radio Pictures
results.brief_description: Atmospheric horror film based on a Robert Louis Stevenson short story. Set in Edinburgh of 1831, a gifted doctor who runs a medical school is haunted by a grave robber who supplied corpses to research scientists and once protected him from a prison term. Cast includes Boris Karloff, Bela Lugosi and Henry Daniell.

results.title: The Little shop of horrors
results.creator_credit: Frank Oz, David Geffen and The Geffen Company
results.brief_description: Originally a film directed by Roger Corman and shot in two days in 1960, then a musical play extravaganza on Broadway in 1982, and finally a multimillion dollar allstar film musical in 1986, “Little shop of horrors,” with its quirkiness, comedy and wonderful satire has developed quite a cult following over the decades. This extremely entertaining version by puppeteer and director Frank Oz (The Dark crystal, The Muppets take Manhattan, Dirty rotten scoundrels, The Empire strikes back [voice of Yoda], Return of the Jedi, The Phantom menace) features Rick Moranis as the nerdy Seymour Krelborn who works in the florist shop near Skid Row, Vincent Gardenia as Mushnik his boss, and Ellen Greene as Audrey, the shop assistant and woman Seymour secretly desires. When Seymour buys a small exotic plant which suddenly appeared after an eclipse of the sun, strange things begin to happen. Audrey II (Seymour’s name for the plant) takes on a personality of its own and develops quite a unique appetite, wanting to be continually fed, not with plant food, but with blood, and the more it is fed, the bigger Audrey II becomes. This monster plant has an insatiable appetite and the dilemma for Seymour is what can he do about it. Nominated for many awards (including Academy Awards, Golden Globe, BAFTA) and winner of the Saturn Award for Best Music (Alan Menken) in the Academy of Science Fiction, Fantasy and Horror Films, 1987. Uses great visual and special effects, with book, lyrics and screenplay by Howard Ashman, music by Alan Menken, music produced by Bob Gaudio, and voice of Audrey II performed by Levi Stubbs of The Four Tops. Cameo roles by Steve Martin (at his brilliant best as the totally demented and sadistic bikie boyfriend of Audrey), James Belushi, Bill Murray, John Candy, Christopher Guest and an excellent support cast including Tichina Arnold, Tisha Campbell and Michelle Weeks.

results.title: Things to come
results.creator_credit: William Cameron Menzies, Alexander Korda and London Film Productions
results.brief_description: Things to come is the famous film adaptation of H.G. Wells’ prophetic novel and futuristic exploration ‘The Shape of Things to Come’. Wells’ futuristic vision of impending global war (chillingly) begins at the outbreak of World War II in 1940. The film shifts to the mid 1960’s to Everytown, a place in ruins ruled by a makeshift warlord on the brink of insanity. The film’s closing act begins in 2036 Everytown, at a time of peace but also uninspiring technological Utopia. Run by scientists the townsfolk eventually resist the directives of the scientists and rebel against their imposed staid futuristic lifestyles. With extraordinary set designs by Vincent Korda. Cast includes Raymond Massey and Ralph Richardson.

results.title: Isle of the dead
results.creator_credit: Mark Robson, Val Lewton and RKO Radio Pictures
results.brief_description: Set in Greece during the 1912 Balkan wars, a group of people are quarantined on a remote island in order to stop a rapidly spreading plague. Amongst the group is the tyranical Greek General Nikolas Pherides (Boris Karlof), a sadistic man who initially orders the quarantine and then begins to terrorize a young peasant girl he believes to be some kind of vampiric demon. Producer Val Lewton, working this time around without the aid of his long time collaborator Jacques Tourneur, (together they collaborated on some of the most eloquent horror films of the 40’s including Cat people and I walked with a zombie) manages to create some chills from the material, (which was originally based on an Arnold Bocklin painting called Isle of the dead) particularly in the film’s eerie buried alive sequence. Cast includes Ellen Drew, Marc Cramer, Katherine Emery, Helen Thimig, Jason Robards Sr.

results.title: The Leopard man
results.creator_credit: Jacques Tourneur, Val Lewton and RKO Radio Pictures
results.brief_description: Is it an escaped leopard or something more sinister that is responsible for some grizzly murders in a New Mexico border town? Teaming up with producer Val Lewton for the third time, director Jacques Tourneur has fashioned an eerie, economical and atmospheric film noir thriller. Based on the Cornell Woolrich novel “Black Alibi”, ‘The Leopard man’ utilizes to great effect, a subtle, moody soundtrack and expressionistic lighting to suggest rather than show, proving that the imagination can sometimes be more terrifying. Like their previous collaboration’s ‘Cat People’ (1942) and ‘I Walked with a Zombie’ (1943), the film is made up of a series of chilling set pieces that unnerve and linger rather than shock in their disquieting tone and atmosphere. Cast includes Margo, Dennis O’Keefe, Jean Brooks, Isabel Jewell and James Bell.

results.title: I Walked with a zombie
results.creator_credit: Jacques Tourneur, Val Lewton and RKO Radio Pictures
results.brief_description: In this hauntingly loose transposition of Charlotte Bronte’s “Jane Eyre” to the West Indies, a nurse, summoned to look after a sick woman, falls in love with the brooding husband and encounters voodoo. An ambiguous combination of horror fantasy and psychological thriller, the film blurs the distinction between good and evil, poetically depicting tribal customs without condescension and stereotyping. Beautifully shot by cinematographer J. Roy Hunt, the shadowy night world pervades everything and everyone.’ I Walked with a Zombie’ stands as the zenith of director Jacques Tourneur and producer Val Lewton’s wonderful horror collaborations. Cast includes James Ellison, Frances Dee and Tom Conway.
